text: good find!
why had I not heard of this before???
some of Hashicorp’s UIs are Ember too
I love Hashicorp
consul :heart:
I think web UI built into Consul is still Ember
this thing: <https://demo.consul.io/ui/>
I’ve had great experiences with consul/diplomat using ruby at SMHW
easiest password management on earth
<@U047GTU64>: have you tried out Vault?
nope
we used consul’s key value store for password management
that looks better suited though
it’s a more recent addition to the stable
saw someone using consul to run arbitrary commands across nodes the other day
hadn’t considered that as a possibility before, but very useful
if a little dangerous :wink:
yeah i think we leveraged that at some point
rarely touched the infraestructure back then, but it was a major improvement over your standard
ssh into something, play around and leave :joy:
yeah I will need to look at all these new Devops tech soon
currently getting more and more into Docker, especially with Docker for Mac almost ready
I can finally get rid of Vagrant once that is stable enough
aww, poor old vagrant :slightly_smiling_face:
IMO the tech stacks for devops provide around the same set of features
but you need to be super tidy when setting up/rotating servers
I dont find it particularly hard
just too many points of failure when you’re doing work
<@U047GTU64>: I saw Mitchell Hashimoto give a talk about Nomad a few months back
superb talk on a superb piece of software

when asked “how does Nomad compare to Kubernetes” he answered something to the effect of “Nomad is dedicated to being an awesome distributed scheduler, whereas Kubernetes folds in many other responsibilities”
Kubernetes is something of a universe unto itself, from what I gather
it’s kinda strange trying to learn about these tools which are targeted at teams running many thousands of nodes across multiple data centres
my experience and use cases are so far removed from the target audience
still, fascinating tech
yeah, we’re not clients per-se
I have some peeps running more distributed systems, they’re using a combo of docker + <https://mesosphere.com/>
it’s kinda surprising how well marketed all these tools are
pretty websites with excellent copy writing
really thoughtful first-run experiences
quite a step from the old sys admin days
though I freely admit I’ve never played that role in any company
I think is because the people behind it are tech-first
and they know how much a developer appreciates a sweet landing page, etc
for example look at Stripe when they launched bitcoin support
<https://stripe.com/bitcoin>
SMOOTH LIKE SILK

> I think is because the people behind it are tech-first
as opposed to business-first?
yeah
b2b2c
opposite to something like salesforce thats more b2b

text: because of the glimmer work
so…
I can see the conversation this morning is got interesting topics … glad to hear Hashicorp is using Ember. We really need to market these things better.
I do have — heaven forbid — have an Ember question (Ember Data specifically)

In cases where you’re using a backend-light solution like Horizon / Firebase and/or a schema-less database like Rethink / Firebase. Do you think supporting some referential integrity on the client side is reasonable?
aka., if I have a 1:M relationship and delete the “1” side; should the references on the “M” side that point to the deleted record get cleaned up by ED?
<@U04BD6KB1|ksnyde> uploaded a file: <https://emberlondon.slack.com/files/ksnyde/F1FDHN39P/pasted_image_at_2016_06_09_12_11_pm.png|here’s the problem statement>

<@U0ASPMFPS>: Ember as it stands isn’t really cut out for TS (go here <https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/ember/ember.d.ts>, and cmd+f for ‘any’ - over a thousand hits!) I’m assuming get() and set() are responsible for most of this, since the TS compiler has no idea what’s coming back from `this.get(‘foo’)`

text: I think that this is how relationships work in ember data if you have inverses (and you do unless you tell ED otherwise)
the ED store is an identity map
so hasMany and belongsTo are always in sync

now, bear in mind, I am working on an adapter
adapter?

and decorators

Hey folks, I’ve created a short video that describes the problem I’m having with my Ember Data adapter. I’d love it if folks could have a quick look and see if anything occurs to you:

<https://vimeo.com/170005309/3ff5bb60d4>
I’ve checked EmberFire and they have nothing special WRT to referential integrity
Going to check base Adapter implementation now
is it possible that the serializer’s normalisation is responsible for this?
<@U04BD6KB1>: It seems to me that this a problem you can solve in your route not in the template
I mean, it’s the route job to load data
so, if you need todos to be loaded, you can either sideload them in your request
yes but the reinforcement of relationships is a key part of Ember Data
or explictly add them
<@U04BD6KB1>: yes but it is not magic
you need to load your data
I’m working on an addon which has Adapter / Serializer so that people can use Horizon out of the box
data is loading, the problem is relationships being updated when data changes
can you show also the content of your network responses?
its all websockets
for the deleted item, how is it deleted?
the adapter i’ve created takes the request, sends WS to Horizon and returns the expected promise
very straight forward
that’s not the problem area (I’m 99%  sure)
it’s within Ember-Data and indications are it’s in the serializer
potentially when you call normalize but that’s just a theory
hmm
not sure
as the payload structure of Horizon is JSON (not JSON-API) I need to check it’s using a subclass of the right serializer
that could be the cause
what’s the structure of your JSON
basic JSON payload (defined by Horizon/ReThink but very standard)
but how are objects linked?
I mean
aka, `id` is “id”, name/value pairs after that
when you list people
do you also get their todos?
only after you’ve populated the TODO’s with a `findAll(’todo’)`
then it works but the template should resolve this dependency from the get-go
I don’t think the template should do it
but I could be wrong
it should
I think you are expecting somenthing from template, which template are not expected to do

OK :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U04BD6KB1>: is your code available somewhere?
also what happens when you click todos first, then click people after

so by having setup the relationship, what I would “expect” to happen is that when I add a TODO with an owner, it populates the TODO’s “ownedBy” relationship _and_ it updates the PERSON’s “owns” hasMany relationship
do you get the say result as when you click people then click todos?

if that happened then the Person would get updated with the reference and then the JSON you’re asking about would have it. The fact is that it does not update the Person record and therefore when loading Person table it get’s no reference to the “owns” column
if I click “todo” then it resolves the person who owns each todo
if I click “person” route (without having previously loaded todos) it does not resolve the todos
so `belongsTo` works, `hasMany` does not
further complicating things, the backend store is schema-less so I have no model definition there but when adding a TODO with an owner it only stores the “belongsTo” relationship
I will pull down the code and have a quick look to see if I can spot anything
also what happens when you remove a person then refresh the page, does that todo get removed? (the end part of your video issue)
